content:
✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Brings back child memories learning this in school. We use it less and less so this is good to refresh some old knowledge as well.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: This problem meets all the criteria for a CoC problem, although a bit long (especially for reverse).  There are no barriers to this becoming a CofC problem.

Not a terribly difficult problem this, but it is 30 - 50 lines of code to solve and handle the decrementing cases.  I found myself at over ten minutes.  That being said, I liked the problem.  There is no clear way to make it shorter without being incomplete.  All three forms work for this problem, though reverse with be very difficult I think, given the extra time needed to work out what is being asked and then to shorten.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Approved, with as reason that I would love to play this clash - the goal is easy enough to understand, and the input is simple, so all time can be spent on coding the answer.
I like this clash. Thank you.

Correct the statement (system instead of sistem)

This can be a great easy puzzle, but the conversion may be to hard to be solved in less than 5 min in many languages.

For the record, there is a puzzle which requires the calculation of the sum of two roman numerals. But unlike this clash, that puzzle also requires the conversion of the sum to a roman numeral.
https://www.codingame.com/training/medium/these-romans-are-crazy!

I see. The puzzle features 2 different problems: converting the Roman numerals into numbers and then converting the sum back to Roman numeral.

I feel like solving both problems is way too hard for a clash, so this could be considered as a simplified version.

Thank you for your comment!

Actually, I'm a bit worried about reverse, too. Personally, I don't think that it is too difficult to notice what is going on. What I am really concerned about is that you *do* need previous knowledge of what Roman numerals are and how they work.

I believe that they are well-known enough, but if you people don't think so, I'll remove reverse from the game modes.

This is news to me.
I ran out of time on this clash anyway, but I believed the description was in fact telling me to keep the whole thing in Roman numerals, from beginning to end.
"Output the sum of two Roman numerals" doesn't suggest to me that the final format would not also be Roman numerals...
Perhaps either "Output the sum of two Roman numerals as a base-10 integer"
or
"Convert two Roman numerals to integers and output their sum"
would have made this clearer.

It is important to check the example input and output ;)

However, I see no reason to not make it clearer in the description, too. I will modify the statement as you suggest.
